headline: 2 Megacaps and 2 Smaller Internet Stocks that Could Outperform in 2025
summary: Many tech stocks had a blowout year, but some are still underperforming the broader market.  This Truist analyst has picked several internet stocks that have been through either booms or busts that he believes will shine in 2025.  Youssef Squali wrote in a research note on Tuesday that he has confidence the positive tailwinds that have helped push some tech stocks higher in 2024, including excitement over artificial intelligence and the strength in e-commerce, will continue in the new year.

headline: Meta Fined $264 Million By EU Watchdog Over 2018 Facebook Data Breach
summary: On Tuesday, The Irish Data Protection Commission (DPC) announced its final decisions following two inquiries into Facebook parent Meta Platforms, Inc (NASDAQ:META) Meta Platforms Ireland Limited (MPIL). The decisions made by the Commissioners for Data Protection, Dr. Des Hogan and Dale Sunderland, included several reprimands and a penalty of approximately $264 million (251 million euros). The DPC launched these own-volition inquiries following a personal data breach reported by MPIL in September

The decisions made by the Commissioners for Data Protection, Dr. Des Hogan and Dale Sunderland, included several reprimands and a penalty of approximately $264 million (251 million euros). The DPC launched these own-volition inquiries following a personal data breach reported by MPIL in September

headline: EU privacy regulator fines Meta 251 million euros for 2018 breach
summary: DUBLIN (Reuters) -The lead European Union data privacy regulator for Meta fined the social media giant 251 million euros ($263.5 million) on Tuesday for a 2018 Facebook security breach that affected 29 million users.  Meta notified Ireland's Data Protection Commission at the time that cyber attackers had exploited a vulnerability in Facebook's code that impacted the "View As" feature that lets users see what their own profile looks like to someone else.

raw.headline: EU privacy regulator fines Meta 251 million euros for 2018 breach
raw.summary: DUBLIN (Reuters) -The lead European Union data privacy regulator for Meta fined the social media giant 251 million euros ($263.5 million) on Tuesday for a 2018 Facebook security breach that affected 29 million users.  Meta notified Ireland's Data Protection Commission at the time that cyber attackers had exploited a vulnerability in Facebook's code that impacted the "View As" feature that lets users see what their own profile looks like to someone else.

headline: Facebook owner hit with 251 million euros in fines for 2018 data breach
summary: European Union privacy watchdogs hit Facebook owner Meta with fines totaling 251 million euros on Monday after an investigation into a 2018 data breach on the social media platform that exposed millions of accounts.  Ireland's Data Protection Commission issued the penalties after wrapping up its inquiry into the breach, when hackers gained access to user accounts by exploiting bugs in the platform’s code that allowed them to steal digital keys, known as “access tokens.”  The watchdog issued reprimands and “administrative penalties” worth 251 million euros ($264 million) after it found multiple infringements of the rules, known as the General Data Protection Regulation.

raw.headline: Facebook owner hit with 251 million euros in fines for 2018 data breach
raw.summary: European Union privacy watchdogs hit Facebook owner Meta with fines totaling 251 million euros on Monday after an investigation into a 2018 data breach on the social media platform that exposed millions of accounts.  Ireland's Data Protection Commission issued the penalties after wrapping up its inquiry into the breach, when hackers gained access to user accounts by exploiting bugs in the platform’s code that allowed them to steal digital keys, known as “access tokens.”  The watchdog issued reprimands and “administrative penalties” worth 251 million euros ($264 million) after it found multiple infringements of the rules, known as the General Data Protection Regulation.

headline: Nvidia, Meta Platforms, and Apple Could Help This Unstoppable ETF turn $500 Per Month Into $1 Million
summary: The artificial intelligence (AI) industry is still in its infancy, but investors already witnessed its incredible potential to create value.  Since the start of 2023, Nvidia's (NASDAQ: NVDA) market capitalization has grown from $360 billion to $3.3 trillion, almost entirely because of soaring sales of its AI data center chips.  It can offer exposure to the value created by AI in a diversified manner, which can insulate investors from severe losses if some companies fail.

raw.headline: Nvidia, Meta Platforms, and Apple Could Help This Unstoppable ETF turn $500 Per Month Into $1 Million

headline: Facebook-parent Meta settles with Australia's privacy watchdog over Cambridge Analytica lawsuit
summary: The Office of the Australian Information Commissioner had alleged that personal information of some users was being disclosed to Facebook's personality quiz app, This is Your Digital Life, as part of the broader scandal.  The breaches were first reported by the Guardian in early 2018, and Facebook received fines from regulators in the United States and the UK in 2019.  Australia's privacy regulator has been caught up in the legal battle with Meta since 2020.

raw.headline: Facebook-parent Meta settles with Australia's privacy watchdog over Cambridge Analytica lawsuit
raw.summary: The Office of the Australian Information Commissioner had alleged that personal information of some users was being disclosed to Facebook's personality quiz app, This is Your Digital Life, as part of the broader scandal.  The breaches were first reported by the Guardian in early 2018, and Facebook received fines from regulators in the United States and the UK in 2019.  Australia's privacy regulator has been caught up in the legal battle with Meta since 2020.

headline: CEOs Are Feeling a Lot More Upbeat About the New Year
summary: CEOs of the world’s biggest companies are more optimistic about the economy than they have been in years.  The enthusiasm is being driven in part by the prospect of President-elect  Donald Trump’s  return to the White House, with many chief executives expecting their businesses to benefit from lower corporate taxes and less regulation, according to a new survey.  Outcomes of other elections around the world are also fueling expectations for improvements in the global economy and political stability.
